unnormalised: ## Beyond Bollywood: Diving into the World of Film Festivals!
normalised: Beyond Bollywood: Diving into the World of Film Festivals!

unnormalised: Hey guys! Ever felt like you're stuck in a loop of watching the same old Bollywood blockbusters on Netflix? Don't get me wrong, I love a good SRK romance as much as the next desi, but there's a whole universe of amazing cinema out there waiting to be discovered, and film festivals are your ticket!

Do not get me wrong, I love a good S R K romance as much as the next desi, but there is a whole universe of amazing cinema out there waiting to be discovered, and film festivals are your ticket!

unnormalised: Think of film festivals as a big, fat Indian wedding for movies. Except instead of distant relatives pinching your cheeks, you have the chance to see cutting-edge films, meet the people behind them, and soak up a vibe that’s pure cinematic magic.
normalised: Think of film festivals as a big, fat Indian wedding for movies. Except instead of distant relatives pinching your cheeks, you have the chance to see cutting-edge films, meet the people behind them, and soak up a vibe that is pure cinematic magic.

unnormalised: India's got some amazing film festivals. We're talking the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) in Goa, a total blast with screenings from all over the world! And for the independent film scene? The Mumbai Film Festival, also known as MAMI, is *the* place to be. It's like IIT for filmmakers, pushing boundaries and showcasing stories you won't see anywhere else. You might even catch a glimpse of Naseeruddin Shah there!
normalised: India has got some amazing film festivals. We are talking the International Film Festival of India (I F F I) in Goa, a total blast with screenings from all over the world! It is like I I T for filmmakers, pushing boundaries and showcasing stories you will not see anywhere else. You might even catch a glimpse of Naseeruddin Shah there!

unnormalised: But it's not just about the big names, ya know? There are smaller, more niche festivals popping up all over, celebrating everything from documentary filmmaking to regional Indian cinema. Just last year, I heard about this cool festival in Kerala dedicated entirely to films about social justice – pretty intense!

unnormalised: So, why should you consider checking out a film festival? Firstly, it's a great way to discover new genres and perspectives. Secondly, it’s a chance to support independent filmmakers who are working hard to tell unique stories. Plus, let's be honest, it's a super cool and cultured thing to do.

unnormalised: Tickets usually cost somewhere around Rs. 500 for a single screening, or you can get a delegate pass for like, Rs. 5000. Worth it, trust me! Just factor in travel (Goa’s like 1500 km from Delhi!) and accommodation.
